trans-unit.source: Exposes methods and properties to support UI Automation client access to a control that acts as a scrollable container for a collection of child objects.
The children of this control must implement <xref href="System.Windows.Automation.Provider.IScrollItemProvider"></xref>.
Implemented on a UI Automation provider that must support the <xref:System.Windows.Automation.ScrollPattern> control pattern.
Gets a value that indicates whether the control can scroll horizontally.
This property can be dynamic.
For example, the content area of the control might not be larger than the current viewable area, meaning HorizontallyScrollable is `false`.
However, either resizing the control or adding child items can increase the bounds of the content area beyond the viewable area, meaning that HorizontallyScrollable is `true`.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the control can scroll horizontally; otherwise <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Gets the current horizontal scroll position.
The horizontal scroll position as a percentage of the total content area within the control.
Gets the current horizontal view size.
The horizontal size of the viewable region as a percentage of the total content area within the control.
Scrolls the visible region of the content area horizontally and vertically.
The horizontal increment specific to the control.
<xref href="System.Windows.Automation.ScrollPatternIdentifiers.NoScroll"></xref> should be passed in if the control cannot be scrolled in this direction.
The vertical increment specific to the control.
<xref href="System.Windows.Automation.ScrollPatternIdentifiers.NoScroll"></xref> should be passed in if the control cannot be scrolled in this direction.

If a control supports <xref href="System.Windows.Automation.ScrollAmount"></xref> values exclusively for horizontal or vertical scrolling but a <xref href="System.Windows.Automation.ScrollAmount"></xref> value is passed in.
An attempt is made to scroll in an unsupported direction.
Sets the horizontal and vertical scroll position as a percentage of the total content area within the control.
This method is only useful when the content area of the control is larger than the visible region.
Passing in the value <xref:System.Windows.Automation.ScrollPatternIdentifiers.NoScroll> indicates that there is no scrolling in the specified direction.
The horizontal position as a percentage of the content area's total range.
<xref href="System.Windows.Automation.ScrollPatternIdentifiers.NoScroll"></xref> should be passed in if the control cannot be scrolled in this direction.
The vertical position as a percentage of the content area's total range.
<xref href="System.Windows.Automation.ScrollPatternIdentifiers.NoScroll"></xref> should be passed in if the control cannot be scrolled in this direction.
A value that cannot be converted to a double is passed in.
A value greater than 100 or less than 0 is passed in (except -1, which is equivalent to <xref href="System.Windows.Automation.ScrollPatternIdentifiers.NoScroll"></xref>).

The <xref:System.Windows.Automation.Provider.IScrollProvider.HorizontalScrollPercent*> and <xref:System.Windows.Automation.Provider.IScrollProvider.VerticalScrollPercent*> values are normalized to either 100 percent or 0 percent.
An attempt is made to scroll in an unsupported direction.
Gets a value that indicates whether the control can scroll vertically.
This property can be dynamic.
For example, the content area of the control might not be larger than the viewable area meaning VerticallyScrollable is `false`.
However, resizing the control or adding child items can increase the bounds of the content area beyond the viewable area, indicating that VerticallyScrollable is `true`.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the control can scroll vertically; otherwise <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Gets the current vertical scroll position.
The vertical scroll position as a percentage of the total content area within the control.
Gets the vertical view size.
The vertical size of the viewable region as a percentage of the total content area within the control.
